sen.j: 京都市内の通り（きょうとしないのとおり）は単なる道路の名前に留まらず、住所を表すためにも用いられる（京都市地理を参照せよ）。
sen.e: The street name in Kyoto City is not only an identifying name to a street but also used to refer to the address. (See maps of Kyoto City)
sen.cmt: 読みは訳していません。
sen.e: The street name in Kyoto City is not only an identifying name to a street but is also used to refer to the address (see "Maps of Kyoto City").
The street name in Kyoto City is not only an identifying name but is also used to refer to the address (see Maps of Kyoto City).

sen.j: この記事では京都市の通りに関する話題と通りの記事の一覧を示す。
sen.e: This article lists up streets in Kyoto City and describes stories about them.
This article lists the streets in Kyoto City and describes them through the use of stories.
This article lists the streets in Kyoto City and describes them through the use of stories.

sen.j: なお、正式な通りの名称の場合「通」に送り仮名は付さない。
sen.e: The official street name is not described with okuriｋana following the Chinese Character “通.”
The official street name is not described with okuriｋana following the Chinese Character “通.”
The official street name is not described with okuriｋana following the Chinese Character '通.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」にあわせて"を'に

sen.j: しかしながら道路標識においては専ら送り仮名が付けられている。
sen.e: However the names with okurigana are often found on traffic signs.
However, the names with okurigana are often found on traffic signs.
However, the names with okurigana are often found on traffic signs.

tit.e: Songs to Learn the Streets by Heart
Songs to Learn the Streets by Heart
Songs to Learn the Streets by Heart

sen.j: 京都市の中心部の東西・南北の通りの名を覚えるために、通りの名前を編み込んだ唄がいくつか知られている。
sen.e: There are several well-known traditional songs whose words are made up of the names of the east-west and north-south running streets of central Kyoto City, to help learn the names by heart.
There are several well-known traditional songs whose words are made up of the names of the east-west and north-south running streets of central Kyoto City, to help learn the names by heart.
There are several well-known traditional songs whose words are made up of the names of the east-west and north-south running streets of central Kyoto City, to help learn the names by heart.

sen.j: その中でも代表的なものが下の2曲である。
sen.e: The following 2 songs are the most typical
The following two songs are the most typical:
The following two songs are the most typical:

sen.j: 節の最初を取り、南北の通りについては寺御幸（てらごこ）、東西の通りについては丸竹夷（まるたけえびす）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: One is called Teragoko for north-south running streets and the other is Marutake Ebisu for east-west running streets, the names of which are the first portion of the words.
One is called "Teragoko" for north-south running streets, and the other is "Marutake Ebisu" for east-west running streets, the names of which are the first portions of the words.
One is called Teragoko for north-south running streets, and the other is Marutake Ebisu for east-west running streets, the names of which are the first portions of the words.

sen.j: なお、丸竹夷が口伝えに伝えられてきたものであるのに対し、寺御幸は一度途絶えてしまったものを、過去の史料をもとに再編したものである。
sen.e: Marutake Ebisu has been passed down by word of mouth generation after generation, while Teragoko was once lost but revised with historical data.
sen.cmt: 「なお」は訳し出ししていません。
sen.e: "Marutake Ebisu" has been passed down by word of mouth generation after generation, while "Teragoko" was once lost but was revised with the help of historical data.
In addition, Marutake Ebisu has been passed down by word of mouth generation after generation, while Teragoko was once lost but was revised with the help of historical data.
sen.cmt: 原文に『』のない" "を削除「なお」を訳出

sen.j: 京都銀行が寺御幸を、聖護院八ツ橋が丸竹夷をコマーシャル・メッセージで使ったこともある。
sen.e: In commercial films, Teragoko was used by Bank of Kyoto and Marutake Ebisu by Shogoin "Yatsuhashi" (cinnamon cookie dough)
In commercial films, "Teragoko" was used by the Bank of Kyoto and "Marutake Ebisu" was used by Shogoin "Yatsuhashi" (cinnamon cookie dough).
In commercial films, Teragoko was used by the Bank of Kyoto and Marutake Ebisu was used by Shogoin Yatsuhashi (cinnamon cookie dough).

sen.j: また、劇場版名探偵コナン『名探偵コナン 迷宮の十字路』にもこれらの唄が使われた。
sen.e: These songs were also sung in "Detective Conan: Crossroad in the Ancient Capital", the movie version of the TV series Meitantei Konan (Detective Konan).

sen.j: 七条越えれば八九条
sen.e: After Shichijo, Hachi-Kujo comes.

sen.j: 十条東寺でとどめさす
sen.e: Jujo, toji comes at the end.
Jujo, toji comes at the end.

sen.j: 尚、雪駄屋町通は現在楊梅通、銭屋町通は現在的場通、魚の棚通は現在六条通。
sen.e: The Settayacho-dori Street, Zeniyacho-dori Street, and Uonotana-dori Street are now called Yobai-dori Street, Matoba-dori Street, and Rokujo-dori Street, respectively.
sen.cmt: http://www5e.biglobe.ne.jp/~hidesan/kyoto-toori-uta.htm現在の「楊梅通」http://www.mutsunohana.net/miyako/oji-koji/yamamomo-koji.htmhttp://www.geocities.jp/satorudate4738/torishokai.htmlhttp://www5e.biglobe.ne.jp/~hidesan/kyoto-toori-uta.htmhttp://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/kurituka/torina.htm尚は訳し出ししていません。
sen.e: Settayacho-dori Street, Zeniyacho-dori Street and Uonotana-dori Street are now called Yobai-dori Street, Matoba-dori Street and Rokujo-dori Street, respectively.
By the way, Settayacho-dori Street, Zeniyacho-dori Street and Uonotana-dori Street are now called Yobai-dori Street, Matoba-dori Street and Rokujo-dori Street, respectively.

sen.j: 三哲は塩小路通。
sen.e: Santetsu means the Shiokoji-dori Street.
Santetsu means Shiokoji-dori Street.
Santetsu means Shiokoji-dori Street.

sen.j: また「東寺」は通りの名前ではない。
sen.e: “To-ji” does not refer to the street but To-ji Temple.
“To-ji” doesn't refer to the street but to the To-ji Temple.
To-ji' doesn't refer to the street but instead to To-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」にあわせて"を'に

sen.j: 下を「五条」で唄を終えることもある。
sen.e: Some songs end with “Gojo,” as the street located lowest in the city.
Some songs end with “Gojo,” as the street located lowest in the city.
Some songs end with 'Gojo,' as the street located lowest in the city.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」にあわせて"を'に

sen.j: また、魚の棚以南の個所には異なって伝わっている歌詞が多くある。
sen.e: Some words describing the streets south of the Uonotana-dori Street have not correctly come down.
Some words describing the streets south of Uonotana-dori Street haven't come down correctly.
Some words describing the streets south of Uonotana-dori Street haven't come down correctly.

sen.j: 古くから歌い慣らされているのは、上記の通り、十条通を歌い込むものだが、三哲通（塩小路通）が七条通より早く歌われるとともに、九条通にある東寺を十条通とともに掲げるなど、実際の通りの順序と異なって歌われている。
sen.e: In songs traditionally sung, which include the Jujo-dori Street in their words like in the song above, the streets are put in an order different from what they are actually put; for example, the Santetsu Street (Shiokoji-dori Street.) comes earlier than the Shichijo-dori Street; Toji-Temple on the Kujo-Street is combined with the Jujo-Street.

In songs traditionally sung, which include Jujo-dori Street in their words as in the song above, the streets are put in an order that is different from what they are actually put; for example, Santetsu Street (Shiokoji-dori Street) comes earlier than Shichijo-dori Street, and Toji-Temple on Kujo-Street is combined with Jujo-Street.

In songs traditionally sung, which include Jujo-dori Street in their words as in the song above, the streets are put in an order that is different from what they are in fact put; for example, Santetsu-dori Street (Shiokoji-dori Street) comes earlier than Shichijo-dori Street, and To-ji Temple on Kujo-Street is combined with Jujo-Street.
sen.cmt: dori補足Toji-Temple→To-ji Temple"actually" -> "in fact" に変更しました。

sen.j: なお、上が丸太町通から始まっているが、江戸時の町家の上手は概ね丸太町から始まり、下は五条程度であった。
sen.e: As is shonw in the song that starts with the Marutamachi-dori Street, the residential areas in the Edo era roughly extended from Marutamachi in the north to Gojo in the south.
As is shown in the song that starts with Marutamachi-dori Street, the residential areas in the Edo era roughly extended from Marutamachi in the north to Gojo in the south.
As is shown in the song that starts with Marutamachi-dori Street, the residential areas in the Edo era roughly extended from Marutamachi in the north to Gojo in the south.

sen.j: また、昭和初期まではその外では田畑も多かった。
sen.e: Until the early Showa era, rice and crop fields were around outside the areas.
Until the early Showa era, those areas were surrounded by rice paddies and crop fields.
Until the early Showa era, those areas were surrounded by rice paddies and crop fields.

sen.j: これを実際の並びの通りに示した歌詞もある（下表参照）。
sen.e: There is another song in which streets are put in an actual order. (See the table below.)

sen.j: 九条東寺でとどめさす
sen.e: Kujo, toji comes at the end
Kujo, toji comes at the end

sen.j: 図子（辻子）と路地
sen.e: Zushi and Alleys
Zushi and Alleys
Zushi and Alleys

sen.j: 地割の内部にアクセスするため、路地が作られる。
sen.e: Residential alleys are built to get access to small corners inside the block.
Residential alleys are built to provide access to small corners within the block.
Residential alleys are built to provide access to small corners within the block.

sen.j: 多くは袋小路で、表の通りから路地への入り口には、門が設けられたり住民の表札が掲げられたりすることがよくある。
sen.e: Most are blind alleys and a gate or nameplate of the resident is often found at the entrance of the alley on the front road.
Most are blind alleys, and a gate or nameplate of the resident is often found at the entrance to the alley on the front road.
Most are blind alleys, and a gate or nameplate of the resident is often found at the entrance to the alley on the front road.

sen.j: 表の家屋の二階が上を覆っている場合もある。
sen.e: Some alleys are covered with the second floor of the main house built on the front road.
Some alleys are covered by the second floor of the main house built on the front road.
Some alleys are covered by the second floor of the main house built on the front road.

sen.j: このように、京都における路地はきわめて内部的なもので、部外者の通行が自由である通りとは画然とした区別がある。
sen.e: As described above, alleys in Kyoto are quite inside-focused and exhibit a clear contrast to the road allowing free passage of strangers.
As described above, alleys in Kyoto are quite inside-focused and exhibit a clear contrast to the road, which allows the free passage of strangers.
As described above, alleys in Kyoto are quite inside-focused and exhibit a clear contrast to the road, which allows the free passage of strangers.

sen.j: 道幅は人の擦れ違いが出来ないようなものから、軽自動車が行き違えるようなものまで様々である。
sen.e: The width varies from alley to alley; some are too narrow for 2 persons to walk past each other; or others are wide enough for two keicar (light motor vehicle) to pass each other.
The width varies from alley to alley; some are too narrow for two persons to walk past each other, but others are wide enough for two keicar (light motor vehicles) to pass each other.
The width varies from alley to alley; some are too narrow for two persons to walk past each other, but others are wide enough for two keicar (light motor vehicles) to pass each other.

sen.j: 先斗町通と木屋町通を繋ぐビルの通路は、建物が現代化されても生き残っている路地といえよう。
sen.e: A pathway found between buildings and crosssing the Pontocho-dori Street and the Kiyamachi-dori Street can be a traditional alley that survives after the buildings have been modernized.
A pathway found between buildings and crossing Pontocho-dori Street and Kiyamachi-dori Street can be a traditional alley that survives the modernization of the buildings.
A pathway found between buildings and crossing Pontocho-dori Street and Kiyamachi-dori Street can be a traditional alley that survives the modernization of the buildings.

sen.j: 袋小路の路地の突き当たりを貫通させ、通路として開放したものを図子（ずし、辻子とも表記する）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Zushi refers to a road that have been made open as a passage by connecting two dead ends of alleys.
sen.cmt: （ずし、辻子とも表記する）は訳し出ししていません。
sen.e: "Zushi" refers to a road that has been made open as a passage by connecting two dead ends of alleys.
Zushi refers to a road that has been made open as a passage by connecting two dead ends of alleys.

sen.j: 路地と異なり、一般の通り抜けが認められている。
sen.e: Unlike alleys, the zushi is open to public.
Unlike alleys, the zushi is open to the public.
Unlike alleys, the zushi is open to the public.

sen.j: 図子には「革堂図子」や「紋屋図子」など、名前がつけられているものがある。
sen.e: Some zushis are called "Kodo-zushi" and others "Monya-zushi".
Some zushis are called "Kodo-zushi," and others "Monya-zushi."
Some zushis are called 'Kodo-zushi,' and others 'Monya-zushi.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」にあわせて"を'に

sen.j: 中心部の町名に「図子」や「突抜」とあるものは図子に由来する。
sen.e: When a area has “Zushi” or Tsukinuke"in its name, it comes from the zushi.
When a area has “Zushi” or Tsukinuke"in its name, it comes from the zushi.
When a area has 'Zushi' or 'Tsukinuke' in its name, it comes from the zushi.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」にあわせて"を'にスペース挿入

sen.j: 背中合わせの路地を繋いで図子とした経緯を物語るものもある。
sen.e: Some Zushis show the evidence that two alleys were combined back to back.
Some zushis show evidence that two alleys were combined back to back.
Some zushis show evidence that two alleys were combined back to back.

sen.j: 中ほどで直角にあるいは鍵の手に折れ、その前後で道幅が違っている。
sen.e: The width of the alley differs in the middle after a right-angle bend.
sen.cmt: 「鍵の手に折れる」も直角に折れると同意味なため訳し出ししていません。
sen.e: The width of the alley differs in the middle after a right-angle bend.
The width of the alley differs in the middle after a right-angle bend.

sen.j: 京都の「通り」の直線的で遠くを見通せる形とは違う姿が図子には見える。
sen.e: The zushi gives aspects different from “Tori” (or streets) in Kyoto, which are straight and offer a far distant view.
sen.cmt: “Tori”として訳すのは初めてなので (or streets) を入れました。
sen.e: The zushi gives aspects different from “Tori” (or streets) in Kyoto, which are straight and offer distant views.
The zushi gives aspects different from 'Tori' (or streets) in Kyoto, which are straight and offer distant views.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」にあわせて"を'に

sen.j: 道幅が狭い通りを単純に路地と呼ぶのではないことに注意が必要である。
sen.e: Note that such a narrow road is not simply called an alley.
Note that such a narrow road isn't simply called an alley.
Note that such a narrow road isn't simply called an alley.

sen.j: 特に図子の集中する地域として、上京区の一条通以北が挙げられる。
sen.e: Such zushiｓ are found concentrated in particular in the area north of the Ichijo-dori Street in Kamigyo Ward.
Such zushiｓ are found concentrated, particularly in the area north of Ichijo-dori Street in Kamigyo ward.
Such zushiｓ are found in concentrated groups, particularly in the area north of Ichijo-dori Street in Kamigyo Ward.

sen.j: この地域はもともと平安京の範囲外だったが、市街地の拡大により南北方向の通りが北に延長された。
sen.e: This area was once the outside Heijokyo but expanded by extending north-south running streets in the northern direction.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This area was once outside Heijokyo, but it was expanded by extending north-south running streets in the northern direction.
This area was once outside Heiankyo, but it was expanded by extending north-south streets in the northern direction.

sen.j: これらを東西方向に連絡するための図子が作られた。
sen.e: To connect these streets in the east-west direction, zushis were built.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Zushis were built in order to connect these streets in the east-west direction.
Zushis were built in order to connect these streets in the east-west direction.
